title: 109_s1444
content: The Act may be cited as the "Trade Adjustment Assistance for Industries Act of 2005". Congress finds that Trade Adjustment Assistance helps workers and agricultural producers affected by trade-related job losses by providing retraining and new job opportunities. The cost of providing this assistance is minimal compared to the overall economic gains from trade liberalization. Import competition due to trade agreements or unfair practices can have widespread effects on domestic industries, warranting eligibility assessments for assistance. Assessing eligibility for trade adjustment assistance on a plant-by-plant basis is inefficient and can lead to unfair and inconsistent results. SEC. 3. OTHER METHODS OF REQUESTING INVESTIGATION. Section 221 of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to allow for the initiation of an investigation to determine eligibility for adjustment assistance for groups of workers or all workers in a specific occupation upon request of the President, U.S. Trade Representative, or congressional committees. Section 221 of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to allow for the initiation of an investigation upon request of the President, U.S. Trade Representative, or congressional committees. This includes filing a resolution under subsection (c) and inserting "request" or "resolution" after "petition" in subsection (a)(3). SEC. 4. NOTIFICATION. Amends Section 224 of the Trade Act of 1974 to require notifications regarding affirmative determinations and safeguards. Notifications are required by the International Trade Commission to the Secretary of Labor and Secretary of Agriculture in cases of affirmative findings of serious injury to domestic industries or threats thereof, as well as in investigations related to agricultural commodities. Additionally, notifications are mandated when affirmative determinations are made under Section 421 of the Trade Act of 1974. Provisions related to various Free Trade Agreement Implementation Acts and agricultural safeguards are outlined in the Trade Act of 1974. The Commissioner of Customs is responsible for enforcing these provisions. The Trade Act of 1974 outlines provisions related to Free Trade Agreement Implementation Acts and agricultural safeguards. The Commissioner of Customs notifies the Secretary of Labor and the Secretary of Agriculture when additional duties are imposed on products under specific trade agreement provisions. The President must notify the Secretary of Labor of positive determinations under various Free Trade Agreement Implementation Acts related to textile safeguards. Additionally, there are provisions regarding antidumping and countervailing duties. Whenever the International Trade Commission makes a final affirmative determination under the Tariff Act of 1930, they must notify the Secretary of Labor and the Secretary of Agriculture for agricultural commodities. SEC. 5. INDUSTRY-WIDE DETERMINATION. Amends Section 223 of the Trade Act of 1974 to require the Secretary to make an industry-wide determination if certain conditions are met regarding workers in a domestic industry or occupation. SEC. 6. COORDINATION WITH OTHER TRADE PROVISIONS. Industry-wide certification based on global safeguards is being amended under the Trade Act of 1974 to remove provisions related to trade adjustment assistance. Additionally, assistance for workers will be provided after receiving a report on serious injury or threat to a domestic industry. The Trade Act of 1974 is being amended to provide assistance to workers in a domestic industry facing serious injury or threat. The President and Secretary of Labor will take necessary actions, including certifying eligible workers for adjustment assistance. The Trade Act of 1974 is being amended to provide adjustment assistance to agricultural commodity producers employed in domestic production. The Trade Act of 1974 is being amended to provide adjustment assistance to agricultural commodity producers employed in domestic production, including industry-wide certification based on bilateral safeguard provisions or antidumping/countervailing duty orders.
